prompt_markdown: In Unix, `fork()` and `exec()` are used together to create new processes. Explain what each does and why they are separate system calls.

criteria.name: fork
criteria.description: Correctly explains fork creates a copy of the calling process

criteria.name: exec
criteria.description: Correctly explains exec replaces the process image with a new program

criteria.name: separation
criteria.description: Explains benefit of separation (flexibility for redirection, pipes, etc.)

expected_key_points: fork creates child process as copy of parent
child gets different PID, fork returns 0 to child
exec loads new program into current process
separation allows setup between fork and exec
common_mistakes: thinking fork starts a new program
thinking exec creates a new process
